title: Uber driver groped passenger as she vomited out of taxi door
text:
Uber driver Temur Shah sexually assaulted his passenger (Picture: Getty/Police)

An Uber driver has been found guilty of sexually assaulting a passenger.

Temur Shah, 45, attacked the woman in his car in the early hours of January 15, 2018, after picking her up from an address in London’s West End.

He had stopped the car when the passenger started feeling unwell during the trip and told her to sit in the front, Isleworth Crown Court heard.

Shah then pounced as she began to vomit out the door after he stopped his taxi for a second time.

He groped her as he leaned over her to open the door and continued to sexually assault her while she was being sick.

After the attack, the passenger told Shah not to touch her again but had to stay in the car as she had no money or battery on her phone in order to call for help.

She reported the incident to police after she was dropped off near her home.

Police then used CCTV and GPS data from Uber to identify Shah.

Temur Shah took advantage of his victim while she was being sick (Picture: Police)

Shah, from Harrow, was charged with sexual assault on January 19 this year and was convicted on Monday after a one-week trial.

He will now be sentenced on November 12 and has had his private hire licence revoked by Transport for London (TfL).

Detective Superintendent Andy Cox, from the Roads and Transport Policing Command, said: “Shah despicably took advantage of his position as a trusted licensed driver and sexually assaulted a passenger in a vulnerable state. His conviction was down to a meticulous investigation which left the jury in no doubt as to his guilt.”

Mandy McGregor, head of transport policing and community safety at TfL, added the attack on the vulnerable passenger was predatory and disgusting and she was pleased justice had been served.

description: An Uber driver has been found guilty of sexually assaulting a passenger.
